snippet: Many states continue to punish juveniles as harshly as they can despite evidence that doing so actually increases recidivism.
abstract: Editorial criticizes states that continue to impose mandatory sentences on juvenile offenders, despite Supreme Court's landmark rulings that young people are 'constitutionally different' from adults; contends issue is not about going easy on criminals but about giving legal meaning to neurological, psychological and emotional vulnerabilities of young people; holds those who make mistakes, even terrible ones, should not be sentenced to die in prison.
lead_paragraph: Many states continue to punish juveniles as harshly as they can despite evidence that doing so actually increases recidivism.
